Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Nasa'i.» I say: This Hadith is in the "Sahihayn" and others via paths from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, with different wordings and abundant benefits, some exceeding others. The author titled it «Recording Hadith in the Prophetic Era», and this portion of it indicating this meaning is extracted in "Sahih Muslim" from two paths: First: From Abu Al-Tufayl who said: «Ali was asked: Did the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, single you out with anything? He said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, did not single us out with anything he did not generalize to the people as a whole, except what is in the sheath of this sword of mine. Then he brought out a scroll written in it: Allah cursed the one who sacrifices to other than Allah, Allah cursed...». He narrated it in «Sacrifices». The other: From Ibrahim Al-Tamimi from his father who said: «Ali bin Abi Talib addressed us and said: Whoever claims that we have anything we read except the Book of Allah and this scroll (he said: and a scroll hanging in the sheath of his sword) has lied. In it are the ages of camels, and things regarding wounds, and in it the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: Madinah is a sanctuary between 'Ayr and Thawr, so whoever introduces an innovation in it...» the Hadith.

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: He narrated it in «Manumission». It is also in Al-Bukhari in «Inheritance» but it does not mention the sheath, though the point of evidence from it is present with him as well. Hadith Seven: (p. 64): «From Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: The likeness of the believer who reads the Quran is like the citron (Utrujjah)... and the likeness of the believer who does not read the Quran is like the date... and the likeness of the sinner who reads the Quran is like the basil... and the likeness of the sinner who does not read the Quran is like the colocynth (Hanzalah)... and the likeness of the righteous companion is like the owner of musk... and the likeness of the evil companion is like the owner of the bellows... Narrated by Abu Dawood.» I say: This is in the "Sahihayn" from the Hadith of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, separately. The four examples related to reading the Quran are in a Hadith in Al-Bukhari in «Foods», «Virtues of the Quran», and «Tawhid», and in Muslim in «Travelers»; both from the path of Qatadah who said: Anas told us from Abu Musa. It is as if the mention of Abu Musa was dropped from Abu Dawood's narration, for it is with him from this route: Qatadah from Anas. He also narrated it in another version like the narration of the two Sheikhs. The other two examples are in another Hadith, and from another path from Abu Musa. Al-Bukhari narrated it in «Sales» and «Slaughters», and Muslim in «Birr and Silah». Hadith Eight: (p. 69) «From Buraydah, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said:

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: 'Whoever says when he reaches morning or when he reaches evening: O Allah, You are my Lord, there is no god but You, You created me...' he enters Paradise. Narrated by Abu Dawood.» I say: This is in "Sahih Al-Bukhari" from the Hadith of Shaddad bin Aws raised [to the Prophet] with it, and he added at the beginning of the supplication: «The Master of Seeking Forgiveness: O Allah...». If the author had preferred it, he would have been correct twice: First because it is more authentic, and second because it contains the addition! 4 - His attribution of the Hadith to other than its extractor, and to one whose extraction is less primary than the Six, and to other than its Companion, and attaching an addition to it from an unreliable source; these are four criticisms: Example of the first: (p. 22): «From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: I did not see anyone more resembling the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, in manner, dignified bearing, and guidance in his standing and sitting than Fatima, daughter of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him. She said: And she used to, when she entered upon the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, he would stand to her, kiss her, and seat her in his place. And the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, used to, when he entered upon her, she would stand from her sitting place, kiss him, and seat him in her place. When the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, became ill, Fatima entered and leaned over him, kissed him, then raised her head and cried, then leaned over him, then raised her head and laughed. So I said: I used to think this one was of the wisest of our women, but behold she is just one of the women. When the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, passed away, I said to her: Tell me about when you leaned over the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, raised your head and cried, then leaned over him, raised your head and laughed, what compelled you to that? She said: I would then be spreading secrets. He informed me that he was dying from this pain of his, so I cried. Then he informed me that I

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: would be the quickest of his family to join him, so that was when I laughed. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Al-Tirmidhi.» I say: This Hadith cannot be correctly attributed except to Al-Tirmidhi alone, for he is the one who narrated it with this completeness in «Al-Manaqib» and said: «A Hasan Gharib Hadith.» As for Abu Dawood, he only narrated from it the story of standing and kissing. This is what the two Sheikhs did not narrate at all; rather, they narrated with another chain the end of it regarding Fatima's crying and laughing, peace be upon her. There is another example, a Hadith he attributed to Abu Dawood which has no basis with him and is very weak, which preceded in the first chapter (Hadith Twenty-Three). A third example is his saying (p. 44): «From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that a young woman entered upon her and said: My father married me to his brother's son to elevate his low status, and I am unwilling. She said: Sit until the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, comes. So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, came, and she informed him. He sent for her father, called him, and placed the matter in her hands. She said: O Messenger of Allah, I have allowed what my father did, but I wanted to teach the women that fathers have no say in the matter. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i.» I say: The Hadith is with Al-Nasa'i in «The Book of Marriage» (2/78) with this context except for the last sentence of it, which is worded: «But I wanted to teach that women have a say in the matter.» Ahmad (6/136) and Al-Daraqutni (386) narrated it with the wording of the book, as did Ibn Majah (1874), except that he made it from the Hadith of Buraydah. Al-Daraqutni (386) and Al-Bayhaqi (7/118) narrated it with Al-Nasa'i's wording and added at its end: «Or not?».

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: Furthermore, the Hadith has a weak chain, because it is from the narration of Kahmas bin Al-Hasan from Abdullah bin Buraydah from Aisha. Al-Daraqutni and Al-Bayhaqi said following it: «And this is Mursal; Ibn Buraydah did not hear from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her.» All narrators from Kahmas said: From Abdullah bin Buraydah from Aisha, except Waki', who said: From Ibn Buraydah from his father who said: then he mentioned it. Ibn Majah narrated it saying: Hannad bin Al-Sari told us, Waki' told us with it. This is a mistake from Hannad, for Imam Ahmad said: Waki' told us, Kahmas told us from Abdullah bin Buraydah from Aisha. And this is the correct view: That the Hadith is from Aisha, agreeing with this narration from Waki' to the narration of the group from Kahmas. Example of the second criticism: (p. 16) «From Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: Whoever gives the Zakat of his wealth seeking reward, he has its reward. And whoever withholds it, we are taking it and half of his wealth, a determination from the determinations of our Lord; the family of Muhammad has no right to any of it. Narrated by Razin.» I say: He is Razin bin Mu'awiyah Abu Al-Hasan Al-Abdari Al-Andalusi Al-Saraqusti, died in the year (535), authored "Tajrid al-Sihah wal-Sunan", and he is the one intended when attributing the Hadith to him. He is not known today [meaning his book is not widely available], but the author and others attribute to him via another book, such as "Jami' al-Usul" by Ibn Al-Athir and "Al-Mishkat" and others. It appears from what scholars quote from him that many Hadiths and additions to texts occurred in his book which have no basis with any of the Imams of Hadith, let alone the Six Books. Among that is the Hadith of Salat al-Ragha'ib, and another Hadith on the virtue of the Faqih, the fabrication of which I explained in my commentary on "Al-Mishkat" (1/84/251), so refer to it if you wish.

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: Because of that, there is no benefit or utility in attributing the Hadith to Razin, especially if the Hadith attributed to him is in some of the Six Sources, like this Hadith. For Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, as well as Al-Darimi, Al-Hakim, Ahmad, and others narrated it from the Hadith of Bahz bin Hakim from his father from his grandfather Mu'awiyah bin Haydah. Its chain is Hasan, and Al-Hakim and Al-Dhahabi authenticated it. Making it from the Hadith of Mu'adh bin Jabal is an illusion by the author or Razin. This serves as another example of the many examples that the author did not collect these Hadiths from the Six Books, but from others that quote from them! Example of the third criticism, which is attributing the Hadith to other than its Companion, is his saying: «From Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: No one greets me except that Allah, Blessed and Exalted, returns my soul to me until I return the greeting to him. Narrated by Abu Dawood.» I say: This is with Abu Dawood at the end of the Book of «Hajj» from the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah, not from the Hadith of Anas! And it has no basis from him as far as we know. There is disagreement regarding the provenance of the Hadith, and the preferred view with us is that it has a Hasan chain. And Allah knows best. Example of the fourth criticism is his saying (p. 50): «From Buraydah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, went out on one of his expeditions. When he returned, a black young woman came and said: I had vowed that if Allah returned you safely, I would beat the Duff (drum) before you and sing. He said to her: If you have vowed, then beat it, otherwise do not. She said: I have vowed. So she began to beat it (Razin added: and say: 'The full moon rose upon us from the valley of Wada', gratitude is obligatory upon us... as long as a caller calls to Allah'

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: then they agreed) So Abu Bakr entered while she was beating... Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi. I say: Razin was unique in mentioning this addition in this Hadith, and it has no basis in any of the paths of the Hadith as far as we know. Al-Tirmidhi narrated it without them as you learned, and likewise Ahmad and others narrated it from Buraydah with a good (Jayyid) chain. It has a witness from the Hadith of Amr bin Shu'ayb from his father from his grandfather without this addition and without what follows it. Abu Dawood narrated it, and the author mentioned it after this. You have known something of Razin's condition in the example of the second criticism. Yes, this addition was narrated in another Hadith, having no relation to this story, with the wording: «When the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, arrived in Madinah, the women, children, and boys began to say: The full moon rose upon us...». Abu Al-Hasan Al-Khila'i narrated it in "Al-Fawa'id" (59/2). However, its chain is perplexing (Mu'dal) and incorrect, and there is objection to its meaning. This is not the place to explain that; rather, it is in "Silsilat al-Ahadith al-Da'ifah" number (590) and will be published in the magazine "Al-Tamaddun Al-Islami" in some issues of the coming year, Allah willing. It is among the wonders that some Sheikhs use it as evidence for the permissibility of the Duff in gatherings of Dhikr (1), even though it contains no mention of the Duff at all, nor is it regarding Dhikr; rather, it is regarding permissible amusement, were the Hadith authentic! 5 - His translation [titling] of the Hadith with what it does not indicate. First - He said (p. 7): «The Companions are the choice of Allah from the people». Then he mentioned the Hadith «The best of people is my generation...». I say: The Hadith is more specific than the claim, and the title is more general, such that Prophets would enter into it, for they are from the people. Are the Companions better than them according to the author?! Or is it stuttering and inadequacy in expression?!

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: Second - He said (p. 8): «Wage for Teaching». Then he mentioned the Hadith «Indeed, the most deserving thing you take a wage for is the Book of Allah». I say: The correct view regarding the Hadith is that it is about taking a wage for Ruqyah (incantation) with the Quran, as held by the Hanafis, not for its recitation, nor for its teaching, due to two matters: First: That the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said the Hadith on the occasion of the group who took a sheep for Ruqyah, then disliked that, so he, peace be upon him, said this Hadith to them. Had the author cited the Hadith as it appeared in its context/cause, he would have been correct. So I append that for him and say: Ibn Abbas said: A group of the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, passed by a water source where there was a stung or bitten person. A man from the people of the water presented himself to them and said: Is there a Raqi (healer) among you? In the water area is a stung or bitten man. So a man from them went and recited the Opening of the Book (Al-Fatihah) over a sheep [as payment condition], so he was cured. He brought the sheep to his companions, but they disliked that and said: You took a wage for the Book of Allah. Until they arrived in Madinah, and they said: O Messenger of Allah, he took a wage for the Book of Allah. So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: Indeed the most deserving...» the Hadith. The other: There are numerous authentic Hadiths contradicting what the author titled the Hadith with. If it is not interpreted as Ruqyah, it conflicts with those Hadiths, and this is not permissible according to the people of knowledge. I have collected a good group of these Hadiths and extracted them in "Silsilat al-Ahadith al-Sahihah" under number (256-260), so I suffice here by mentioning two of them with brevity in extraction, saying: First: From Abu Darda that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: «Whoever takes a bow for teaching the Quran, Allah will hang upon him a bow of fire on the Day of Resurrection.»

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: Narrated by Abu Muhammad Al-Makhladi in "Al-Fawa'id" and Al-Bayhaqi with a good (Jayyid) chain as said by Ibn Al-Turkmani. Hadith Two: From Abd al-Rahman bin Shibl Al-Ansari who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, saying: «Read the Quran, and do not eat by it, do not seek increase by it, do not turn away from it, and do not go to extremes in it.» Narrated by Ahmad, Al-Tahawi, and others with a strong chain as said by Al-Hafiz in "Al-Fath". Third - He said (p. 12): «The sin whose punishment is multiplied is death». Then he mentioned the Hadith of Al-Bara' regarding striking the neck of the one who married his father's wife. The statement on this is like the statement on the first example, for the title is more general than the Hadith, and it gives the illusion that everyone who commits a multiplied sin receives the death penalty. For example, it is authentic from the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: «For a man to commit adultery with ten women is lighter upon him than to commit adultery with his neighbor's wife.» Does the author say that the adulterer with his neighbor's wife receives the death penalty even if he is not married (Muhsan)?! Similar to it: Fourth - He said (p. 17): «The Haram is not a cure, but it is a disease». Then he mentioned the Hadith of Khamr (alcohol): «It is not a cure, but it is a disease.» This, as you see, is specific to Khamr, so it is not permissible to extend it to all prohibited medicines like anesthetic (Banj) for example. Fifth - He said (p. 22): «The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, used to, when Fatima entered upon him, stand for her and kiss her». Then he cited the Hadith of Aisha «that Fatima used to, when she entered upon the Prophet, he would stand to her, kiss her, and seat her in his place, and the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, used to, when he entered upon her...» so he mentioned similar to it, and it passed in its entirety on p. 44 from the narration of Al-Tirmidhi.

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: I say: This title is an error as appears with the slightest reflection. This is because the Hadith says: «stood to her» (Qama ilayha), and did not say: «stood for her» (Qama laha) as in the title. Standing *to* a person means going to them and ending up at them, contrary to «standing *for* him», for this does not necessitate anything but standing. The narration of Abu Dawood is more explicit in indicating this meaning, and its wording is: «She used to, when she entered upon him, he stood to her, took her hand, kissed her, and seated her in his place. And he used to, when he entered upon her, she stood to him, took his hand, kissed him, and seated him in her place.» This is explicit that the standing from him, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, to her, was only going to her to receive her, evidenced by his taking her hand and his kissing her, may Allah be pleased with her. Standing for reception is legislated and there is no dispute about it due to this Hadith and others with its meaning. This is contrary to the standing that people are accustomed to today, for it is disliked (Makruh) evidenced by the saying of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: «There was no person more beloved to them than the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, yet they would not stand for him, because they knew of his dislike for that.» Narrated by Al-Bukhari in "Al-Adab Al-Mufrad" with an authentic chain according to the condition of Muslim. So what Lady Fatima used to do for him, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, which is standing *to* him, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, is different from what he, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, used to dislike, which is standing *for* him, as is apparent. So there is no contradiction between the two Hadiths, and praise be to Allah. If this is known, it becomes clear that there is also no contradiction between this Hadith of Anas and his saying, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, in the Hadith of Al-Bukhari: «Stand to your master», because it is not a command for the disliked standing; rather, it is a command to stand *to* the master and go to him. So it is like Fatima's standing *to* him, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him. Moreover, the explicit mention of that came in this Hadith in a proven narration with the wording «Stand to your master and bring him down.» See if you wish the discussion on it in "Silsilat al-Ahadith al-Sahihah" (number 66).

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: The summary of the speech is that the author's translation [titling] of the Hadith that the Messenger, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, used to stand *for* Fatima when she entered upon him is a clear error, resulting from a lack of reflection on the text and its context, and from a lack of attention to the difference between «stood for so-and-so» and «stood to so-and-so» in the Arabic style, and a lack of recalling the Hadiths reported in the chapter which help the researcher avoid such an error. And infallibility belongs to Allah alone. Sixth - He said (p. 24): «The texts have encompassed every ruling until the Day of Resurrection». Then he cited under it the Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri who said: «The Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, led us in the Asr prayer one day by day, then stood addressing us, and he did not leave anything that will happen until the establishment of the Hour except that he informed us of it...». And he mentioned other Hadiths with its meaning. I say: I do not know how the author understands from this Hadith and those with its meaning this wide, comprehensive meaning, from such Hadiths which are specific to the Signs of the Hour and what will happen of great events until the Day of Resurrection. Is it conceivable that the Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, would mention all the texts of Sharia encompassing every ruling in one sitting, no matter how long this sitting was? And if it is said that this is possible by way of breaking the norm for him, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, is it possible for a human mind to encompass all of that and retain it?! Seventh - He said (p. 27): «For the worker in the state is a wife, a servant, and a dwelling...». Then he mentioned under it the Hadith «Whoever is a worker for us, let him acquire a wife, and if he does not have a servant, let him acquire a servant...». I say: It appears the author intended by (the worker in the state) the employee in it, whatever employee he is. And (the Worker - Al-Amil) with this meaning is something we do not know in the language; rather, it came in it with three meanings:

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: First: The Caliph, as in the Hadith «I have not left behind [anything except] the expenditure of my family and the provision of my worker (Amil) as charity.» It says in "Al-Nihayah" and "Al-Lisan": «He intended by (my worker) the Caliph after him.» Second: The one who manages a man's affairs regarding his wealth, property, and work. From it, the one who extracts Zakat is called: Amil. He is the one meant in the verse of charities {and those working to collect it} (Al-Amilina Alayha), and they are the collectors (Jubah). Third: The governor (Wali) whom the Sultan appoints over some lands. It came in "Al-Lisan": «So-and-so was employed (ista'mala) meaning he was given charge of a work from the works of the Sultan.» The intended meaning of the Hadith is the second meaning, as appears from Abu Dawood's categorization of it with his saying «Chapter on the Sustenance of Workers (Amilin)» and the Hadiths he listed in it like this Hadith. And the Hadith of Buraydah raised [to the Prophet] with the wording «Whoever we employ on a job and provide him with sustenance, then whatever he takes after that is betrayal (Ghalul).» Imam Al-Khattabi proceeded on this meaning in his explanation of the Hadith in his book "Ma'alim al-Sunan" (4/201), so whoever wishes may refer to it. I say: It is as if in the Hadith of Buraydah there is an indication of the secret behind specifying this ruling to the workers whose job is collecting charities from their owners, which is to enrich them beyond needing what they might need of a wife and servant, and to help them perform what is in their hands of wealth fully and completely. And Allah knows best. Eighth - Then he said (p. 50): «Beating the Duff and singing before the Messenger of Allah». Then he mentioned the Hadith of Buraydah in which we discussed the addition added by Razin previously (p. 47), and in it is the permission of the Messenger, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, to the woman who had vowed that if Allah returned His Prophet safely, she would beat the Duff before him and sing, so he, peace be upon him, permitted her.

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: This is specific to beating the Duff and singing in this situation which will not recur, and the title is more general, so it is feared that some people of desires will cling to it, using it as evidence for general permissibility, and thus go astray. Refer to "Ma'alim al-Sunan" (4/382). Ninth - He said (p. 52): «Surplus wealth is the right of others». And he mentioned under it the Hadith «The son of Adam has no right in other than these characteristics...». Besides being a denounced (Munkar) Hadith with a weak chain as previously explained (p. 25), it does not indicate that what is other than the mentioned characteristics in it of wealth is a right for others that is obligatory for them. Al-Qadi said: «He intended by 'right' what is due to him from Allah without consequence in the Hereafter nor questioning about it, because these characteristics are among the rights that the self cannot do without, and whatever is other than them is from the fortunes about which one is questioned.» If his eminence the Sheikh sees what he titled the Hadith with as correct, has he himself undertaken fulfilling this right for others?! Tenth - Then he said (p. 53): «None of us has a right to surplus wealth». Then he mentioned the Hadith of Abu Sa'id «While we were on a journey, behold a man on a mount of his, he said: He began turning his gaze right and left, so the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, said: Whoever has a surplus mount, let him return it to the one who has no mount, and whoever has surplus provision, let him return it to the one who has no provision. And he mentioned of the categories of wealth what he mentioned, until we saw that none of us had a right to any surplus.» Narrated by Muslim and Abu Dawood. I say: This does not indicate what he titled it for; rather, [the title] is more general than it. It only indicates that he has no right to surplus wealth if there is someone in dire need of it, so it becomes obligatory then to give out from this surplus to him. This is among the rights of wealth that become obligatory due to an occurrence, like his saying, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him: «Free the captive, and feed the hungry.»

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: Narrated by Al-Bukhari. It does not mean that no one has a right to surplus wealth absolutely; otherwise, that would contradict the definitive texts regarding the inviolability of wealth and its prohibition to others except with the willing heart of its owner. And how could it be so when senior Companions died having much surplus wealth, as is known from the condition of Uthman, Abd al-Rahman bin Awf, and others from the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, and the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, approved them on that and did not obligate them to exit from it!! Eleventh - He said (p. 67): «The Petroleum of Iraq». And he mentioned under it the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah from his saying, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him: «The Hour will not be established until the Euphrates uncovers a mountain of gold, over which people will fight, so ninety-nine out of every hundred will be killed...». Al-Bukhari and Muslim. I say: There is no mention of petroleum in the Hadith at all, neither explicitly nor implicitly. Perhaps when the Professor Author saw people today agreeing to call petroleum "Black Gold", it occurred to him to interpret the Hadith with it, imagining that by doing so he presents to people a new scientific proof of the greatness of Islam and its miraculous nature! He missed that it is not permissible in the Sharia to interpret its texts with modern terminologies. For example, it is not permissible to interpret His saying, Exalted is He, {All that - its evil was ever hateful to your Lord} meaning not prohibited (Ghayr Muharram) because it is an interpretation by terminology [where Makruh means disliked but not Haram in Fiqh terminology]. Nor his saying, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, in the Hadith «Six whom Allah cursed... and the one who abandons my Sunnah» meaning the one who abandons the Sunnah which is below the Fard (Obligatory), as I had explained in my book "Tahdhir al-Sajid" (p. 37-38). Furthermore, the mentioned terminology did not apply the name Gold to petroleum absolutely, but restricted it as Black. So if it were permissible to interpret the Hadith with modern terminologies

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: - and this is false - this interpretation would not be permissible here because Gold is absolute [unrestricted] in the Hadith, and the absolute runs upon its absoluteness as is the rule with the scholars. Then, did what he, peace be upon him, informed of occur according to this interpretation? Meaning, did people fight over it such that ninety-nine out of every hundred were killed?! If it is said: It is not necessary that it has happened, but it will definitely happen, we say: Yes, so why then do we not leave the Hadith as every Arab who has not been influenced by modern terminologies understands it, and say that what the Messenger, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, informed of will definitely happen? By that, we dispense with such interpretation which is the essence of negating (Ta'til) the Hadith meanings, agreeing with the methods of the Batiniyyah! It is strange that the author repeated this title after three Hadiths, and listed under it the Hadith of Ubayy bin Ka'b with the meaning of Abu Hurayrah's Hadith! 6 - His listing of Hadiths the knowledge of which entails no great benefit today, under the following titles: (p. 21): «Seeking blessings (Tabarruk) from the traces of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, by his command». And he mentioned in it the Hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib, containing his command, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, to him and another to drink from a vessel he, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, had rinsed his mouth in and to pour it on their faces. Then he said: «The Companions seeking blessings from the traces of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him». Then he listed in it the Hadith of Talq bin Ali, containing that he, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, performed ablution and rinsed his mouth then poured it into a vessel of theirs. Then he repeated the same title and mentioned under it a third Hadith regarding Asma seeking blessings from the Jubbah (cloak) of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him. Then he repeated the title for the fourth time and listed in it a Hadith regarding Umm Salamah seeking blessings from the hair of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him. So what is the benefit of repeating these titles and headings at a time when it is impossible today to seek blessings from his traces, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, due to their non-existence?! And what they do in some lands of seeking blessings on some occasions from a hair preserved in a glass bottle is something that has no basis in the Sharia, nor is that proven by an authentic path.

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: Yes, only some Sheikhs of the Tariqahs [Sufi orders] benefit from these titles as previously mentioned in the introduction. Perhaps the author placed these titles as assistance from him to them in enslaving their disciples and subjecting them to themselves in the name of seeking blessings from them! And Allah is the One sought for help. Then he said (p. 23): «Kissing the hand of the Messenger and his feet»! Then he cited a Hadith in which two Jews kissed his hand, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, and his foot! I say: Even though the validity of the Hadith is questionable as previously explained in its place (p. 14), does the Sheikh intend by that to legislate for people that the disciple should kiss the foot of his Sheikh as well, relying on the action of the two Jews?! If it is said: But the Messenger, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, approved them on that, it is said: Establish the throne then engrave [prove the basis then argue the details], for the Hadith is not proven as we mentioned. And even if it were proven, it is not permissible to analogize the Muslim with the Jew, because honor belongs to Allah, His Messenger, and the believers. So if he, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, approved the two Jews kissing his foot, it does not necessitate approving the Muslim on the likes of it, because he [the Muslim] is honorable and that one is humiliated and abased. So what analogy on the face of the earth is more corrupt than this, that the Muslim is analogized with the Disbeliever, and the honorable with the humiliated?! And even if it were permissible, it is not permissible for any Sheikh to analogize himself with the Messenger, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, permitting for himself what was permissible for him, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him! Because it is from the category of analogizing blacksmiths with angels! Or it is at least an analogy with a discrepancy (Qiyas ma'a al-Fariq)! Then he said (p. 42): «Manumission of slave girls then marrying them». And he mentioned under it an authentic Hadith. Then he said: «Let the owner say 'my boy' and 'my girl'». And he mentioned under it an authentic Hadith. Then he said (p. 49): «Whoever slaps a slave, his expiation is freeing him». Then he mentioned under it an authentic Hadith.

book_title: Critique of «Hadith Texts in General Culture» collected and classified by Muhammad Al-Muntasir Al-Kattani, Professor of Hadith
text: Then he said (p. 56): «Jihad is obligatory with every righteous and sinner». And he mentioned under it the Hadith «Jihad is obligatory with every commander...». I say: Even though the Hadith has a weak chain as previously explained in its place (p. 24), where is Jihad today - regrettably - so that students are reminded of the obligation of Jihad with every commander even if he is a sinner, or is the intention of the title to indicate that Jihad is obligatory with every commander, even if he is the one who commanded himself by himself and was a sinner ruling by other than what Allah revealed, and seeing in his rule clear disbelief (Kufr Bawah)?! Then where are the slaves and slave girls taken by a legitimate method so that we apply those Hadiths to them?! Or is the intent of those repeated titles to justify the enslavement present today in some lands which the Noble Sharia does not allow? This is the last of what was facilitated for us to mention and alert upon in this haste, hoping from Allah Almighty that He benefits the Muslims generally, and the students specifically with it, and that He makes our deeds purely for His Face, and in agreement with the guidance of His Prophet, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him. Indeed, He is the best One asked.
